post_text: Social distancing AP Biology painted lady butterfly release! A month ago Ms. Deuell drove many miles to deliver tiny, but ugly, little caterpillars to her AP biology students homes. So many fun labs had to be scrapped with remote learning. But this one lab they could do, thanks to some generous sponsors who bought the students butterfly cages. Throughout the month they shared pictures, worries about killing them, the rate of growth depending on temperature, videos and excitement over chrysalides forming and butterflies emerging. The release was done on the last day of school. Not exactly how it normally ends but seeing her students all together again even distanced with masks, gave her some closure, hope, and a full heart. Big thanks to Jill La Vallee and Mr. Deshaies for helping take photos of the release!

She will be moving on to the National level. Cate will be busy revising her presentation to compete with students from around the country.

Important: Food Pick-Up/Delivery - Change in Schedule

Hello Families,

Starting this week, we will be offering meal pick-up/delivery service on Mondays and Wednesdays only. This does not mean that you will receive fewer meals. This means that you will receive multiple days of food in one pick-up and/or delivery. The pick-up/delivery locations/times have not changed.

Summary:
Food Pick-Up for All Students: BHS and CES, 8 AM - 11 AM, Monday and Wednesday only.

Belmont Middle School was visited by the New England author and illustrator John Steven Gurney. Mr. Gurney talked about writing books, working with editors, and making pictures come alive with groups of students in grades 5 and 6. During his workshop presentation, the kids had a chance to illustrate their own short stories. There was a lot of creativity and laughter!

John Steven Gurney is the author and illustrator of the graphic novel Fuzzy Baseball and the picture book Dinosaur Train. He has illustrated over 140 chapter books, including the A to Z Mysteries, the Bailey School Kids, and The Calendar Mysteries series. He has illustrated board games, advertising, posters, puzzles, and a shopping bag for the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day parade. John has worked as a caricature artist from Atlantic City to Las Vegas, and on the streets of New York City, but primarily in New England. Since 2002 he has visited schools in 31 different states, and five countries. John lives in Brattleboro, Vermont.

post_text: Dr. Rick Fienberk Visits BHS - On November 21st, the BHS Astronomy Class welcomed speaker Dr. Rick Fienberg to share with the class highlights of astronomical discoveries of 2019 - and a look at what is to come in the future. This visit was a real privilege as Dr. Fienberg is the Press Officer of the American Astronomical Society, one of the largest professional astronomy organizations in the world (he puts out over 1,200 press releases to the world in a year). He was also editor in chief of Sky and Telescope magazine, has stood on both the north and south poles, and even has an asteroid named after him! Though a professional astronomer by education and trade, he enjoys amateur astronomy and inspiring astronomy enthusiasts of all ages.

post_text: Astronomy Club Boldly Goes...to the Crilley Radio Observatory - On November 20th, members of the BHS Astronomy Club headed to Dunbarton, NH, to visit a one-man space exploration center! In the words of student Seth Rupp, Mr. Crilley’s “radio telescopes are pointed to an area in the sky near Rigel, in the constellation Orion. The ‘messages’ received could possibly be ‘chunks’ of one larger message. One theory Mr. Crilley put forward was that whatever is sending the message [may be] sending to different locations on purpose, making us work together in order to decipher the message...It was really fascinating to see the amount of work and dedication Mr. Crilley has put toward this field, and the sheer amount of data he has collected.”

post_text: Under the guidance of high school science teacher Kevin Charleston, BHS students Joey Spinale, Mercede McIntyre, Seth Rupp, and Olivia Bowser recently competed in the qualifying round of the Granite State Challenge, which is similar to the TV game show Jeopardy (except the contestants are high school students and compete as a collaborative team). The BHS team competed at the "Super Saturday" qualifying round and represented us well, but not quite well enough to qualify for the games that appear on NHPTV - only 14 teams make it to TV, so it’s quite competitive (about sixty teams were at the event at Manchester Community College). The kids really enjoyed using their intelligence in competition, especially since they have the opportunity to work as a group to answer questions. Also, in January, New Hampshire Magazine is doing a piece on Granite State Challenge, and they are using a picture of two of our students, Olivia B. and Mercede M. - so that's pretty awesome for BHS!

post_text: CES students had the opportunity to visit with the firefighters at Canterbury Fire & Rescue today as part of Fire Prevention Week. Captain Simpson spent time reviewing fire prevention, fire safety and when to call 911. The students then got to learn about all of the gear the firefighters use. The students were encouraged to discuss fire safety with their families and to make sure they have a plan in place in the event of a fire. He also suggested that smoke alarm batteries be changed often.

post_text: Here are some photos from Tuesday's Career Talk with Guest Speaker, Carol Kline. She spoke to students about her career path as an author, editor, ghost writer, and motivational speaker! She shared many stories but the most inspiring was how her life changed in a pivotal way when she started writing Chicken Soup for the Pet Lover's Soul.

post_text: CES learners in kindergarten, first and second grade spent time this afternoon making holiday cards for members of the military. The students are going to make 500 cards by the end of this month that will be sent to Dr. Laura Landerman-Garber who leads the Holiday Cards 4 Our Military - NH Challenge. Dr. Landerman-Garber is hoping to send off 25,000 cards to members of the armed services – 5,000 to each of the country’s five branches.

post_text: Belmont Elementary School students in grades K-4 all were sent home today with a Home Performance Task for students to complete with their parents or guardians. The task for students is simply to make a peanut (or sun) butter and jelly sandwich. The goal of the activity is to engage students and parents in a discussion about proficiency scales and how they are used to help students understand learning expectations and measure progress in their learning. Parents/guardians are asked to please support your students in this learning opportunity and return the survey at the end of the activity in the Home Performance Task envelope. Simply send it back to school in your son or daughter's backpack. See Mr. Hill's email sent this morning for information on upcoming events planned to guide families to a better understanding of how students will be assessed and what grade reports will look like as we move forward with competency-based education!

post_text: Mrs. Desborough held a book tasting for the fourth grade students yesterday at CES. The students had the opportunity to review each of the books that are nominated for the Great Stone Face Book Award. The Great Stone Face Book Award is given annually to an author whose book receives the most votes from 4th through 6th graders throughout the state. The students will get to vote in April, but previewing each book allows them to determine which ones to add to their reading lists.

post_text: Belmont Elementary School welcomed 18 student leaders to its Student Council on Tuesday evening. Student Council Adviser, Mrs. King, discussed the important role the students now share as leaders and role models for their peers. Mr. Hill congratulated the students and shared his perspective on the significance of their responsibility to represent the student voice, working with administration to make the learning experience at BES fun and engaging for all students. The students’ first action as members included creating posters with positive messages aligned with the school theme, “There’s Only One You!”, and displaying them across the school.

Students in Ms. Iversen's grade three class went to work for The Array Bakery last week, working on multiplication strategies in a fun learning environment! Mr. Hill noted this lesson as a great example of the extra effort that so many teachers put in outside of the school day to develop engaging learning experiences for our students.

You may also notice the Learning Target displayed in the title photo for The Array Bakery. As Belmont Elementary School moves forward into the world of Competency-Based Education, students, staff, and families will be learning more about Standards and Learning Targets. Standards are non-negotiable, measurable learning objectives that guide instruction. Content specific standards are developed at the local, state, or national level. Learning Targets describe, in language students can understand, what students will know or be able to do by the end of a lesson. Standards are frequently broken down into a series of manageable learning targets ("I know" and "I can" statements) that teachers and students use to discuss student learning goals.
